comments.text:
Good question.

Perhaps a good start point is to think of a CPU. From the perspective of 
the computer, events occur in discrete flashes, and time is experienced at 
a rate exactly proportional to its own clock speed.

Organic brains aren't so clean but if we imagine creatures with a faster 
metabolism having faster analytic rate then yes time would defintely move 
slower.

I would say time actually moves faster for an older human than a younger, 
though there may also be another mechanism at play here-the more 
experienced we are the more repetitious and mundane our life happenings, 
the easier they compress in our recent memory-years seem to disappear much 
faster, when in childhood they didn't.

Perhaps a good example of how the mind plays tricks on us...

comments.text:
The short answer: "the power or right to act, speak, or think as one wants 
without hindrance or restraint. the absence of necessity, coercion, or 
constraint in choice or action" is the definition of freedom. Therefore the 
fact that we can sit here arguing our opinions on this quite esoteric 
frivolity (compared to say... what people before 'modern society' had to 
worry about like hunting for dinner and trying to stay alive past 30) means 
that you are enjoying the current system and fruition of civilization. You 
**have** freedom, what you seem to want is anarchy.
Fun fact: The average caveman had a lifespan of about 14 years...
Edited: After actually taking the time and look at those videos you said to 
see.... i realized that you are referring to something else entirely (I 
wrote most of this before doing that and im not gonna delete it lol). 
Still, you're original statement is quite crude and ignorant. As what 
Michael does in all of his videos is lay out the facts, it us up to you or 
anyone else to interpret them as you will. Based on these facts and the 
definition of what we call civilization and progress, we are indeed going 
forward. Whether or not people realize that they are being 'turned into 
bricks' have nothing to do with this channel, and everything to do with 
people like you who misread and misunderstand the facts and go spouting 
nonsense. ie. the dunning-kruger effect.

The long answer: 
I sort of understand what SeanMauer is saying.... I had to put down my 
natural aversion to that flag in his pic... but due to the fact that he did 
not once come out and say what his definition of 'freedom' is and thus did 
not corroborate what many people are thinking (that he is pro-slavery) I 
think he may mean the freedom in which the Civil War was truly fought 
for.... I dont feel like explaining it all, but in essence, if you don't 
already know, the civil war was not fought over slavery, but the 
Confederate's 'States Rights' meaning their freedom to do whatever the hell 
they wanted and not conform to the Union's 'government' or congress. 
Therefore I do agree that that kind of freedom is the ideal goal of 
'civilization' where you dont have to follow someone else's rules or 
standards (kinda like living in your own home rather than having to live 
with your parents)... however, one must realize that, for one, most of the 
confederate states were full of racist, sexist, greedy pigheads (the same 
can be said for some in the union but at least they weren't as open with 
it) who in fact created slavery as we know it today (in most cases in 
history it was more or less indentured servitude or pow). Subsequently, 
that kind of freedom can never be had as long as good ole Human Greed 
persists.
I read a book (albeit a NF Fantasy) where the inhabitants of their planets 
(made up of a variety of humans, dragons, elves, dwarves, etc) created the 
perfect society by making everybody swear an oath on an extremely powerful 
stone that made them unable to cause harm to any other sentient being. Thus 
there is no cause for any governmental system or 'oligarchies' or 
'elitists' or 'rulers' or anybody to tell somebody what to do... as there 
was no longer any reason or ability to cause a conflict. They even managed 
to meat out if it was okay to have sex in your front yard in view of the 
public and other more specific nuances usually related to cultural 
varieties.
Now of course in real life there is no convenient way to stop people from 
infringing on other peoples human rights so such a Utopia can never be had 
as of yet.... however I for one believe that, at the rate technology is 
going, in another second of the history of the world, we will have the 
ability to create anything; which means no race for resources, which means 
there would be nothing to fight over. At this point in time we would have 
created even more complex and lucrative government systems then we do now 
to cover stuff like limiting how many donuts we can replicate or whatever, 
we would concentrate more and more on gaining knowledge for knowledge sake 
, we would not have to worry about having to work for a living as we could 
create anything in our own homes (like how we dont have to go hunt for food 
now, but merely walk to the nearest store). So all we would do to entertain 
ourselves, and the only thing to worry about is our arts and our science... 
This is the very definition of 'civilization' : " the stage of human social 
development and organization that is considered most advanced." -Google 
"An advanced state of intellectual, cultural, and material development in 
human society, marked by progress in the arts and sciences, the extensive 
use of record-keeping, including writing, and the appearance of complex 
political and social institutions." -thefreedictionary.com
"a relatively high level of cultural and technological development; 
specifically :  the stage of cultural development at which writing and the 
keeping of written records is attained" -mariam-webster 
Already society embodies these definitions as opposed to going around being 
able to gather as much money, land, women, and slaves as possible.
Freedom is defined as: 
"the power or right to act, speak, or think as one wants without hindrance 
or restraint." -Google
"the absence of necessity, coercion, or constraint in choice or action" 
-mariam-webster
 "the right to do what you want, make your own decisions, and express your 
own opinions" -the american dictionary
When society has advanced to a point where technology makes it unnecessary 
to have to depend on others or risk your life to sustain your life than 
yeah, thats pretty much the epitome of freedom.

This is progress. Maybe you simply *prefer* the Stone Age. *Simpler* times 
when the complexities of 'human rights' were not even considered.

Seems I have the time to research information and make use of these 
apparently limitless chat boxes... hows that for #Progress #Civilization 
and #Freedom 

As for the edited version of this, after looking at Bricks or Stones and 
dismissing Divide and Conquer (seeing that is was your own video, and not a 
very well done one at that). I must say that you seem to be completely 
misinterpreting the bible, as wells as that rabbi. Firstly, most current 
day 'preachers' and 'religious leaders' pander to their own delegation of 
bricks just as much if not more so then corrupt political leaders and 
corrupt businesses. I truly understand what he meant, and I even went and 
did a little research on my own about the subject. Bricks are the masses 
that are herded into believing whatever is on mainstream; they are the 
ignorant people who do not go out and find facts for themselves; they are 
the ones too willing to unknowingly be slaves. Bricks are the **figurative** 
abominations of God's naturally created Stones. Bricks are the 
personification of human kind's ego, god-complex, and foolhardiness. While 
Stones are the personification of how God made humans 'in his image' and 
how he loves every single human regardless of their differences. Ideally, 
we should be able to complement and live peaceably yet diversely as stones 
do (like a giant jigsaw puzzle). Instead today's society seems to be made 
up of a bunch of brainwashed, ignorant people who are as diverse as bricks 
and stuck together by the Motar of mass media bull crap (to put it 
frankly). And I agree, we should be like Stones, different yet 
complimentary of each other, rather than trying to make everyone believe, 
do, look, act, and be the same way. However, the very fact that we are here 
educating ourselves with the facts of history, should humble us and make us 
more appreciative of how far we have come as a society, we are more unified 
in our diversity then ever before thanks to the pursuit of knowledge, 
thanks to us trying to be more civilized by focusing on art and science... 
We are now, or soon will be at a turning point in history, where we could 
be lost in ignorance, controlled by the mass media being directed by the 
elitists of the world; or advance to a point where all Stones can be 
treated equal, and knowledge is preferred over ignorance. However, if you 
really want to dive into the rabbit hole of who are the 'brick makers' that 
are 'building the modern day Tower of Babylon' ... look up the free-masons.

comments.text:
Trivial, first off the word is "affected," not "effected."

Second of all, you don't have to censor the word "shit." I doubt your 
mother is going to read your comment and be ashamed.

And every aspect of his laws explains how gravity effects motion, and how 
motion works even outside of gravity.

Newton's First law states than an object at rest tends to stay at rest and 
an object at motion tends to stay at motion, unless acted upon by a greater 
or equal force.

All that this first law states is that if it's moving, it will keep moving 
until stopped. Now, on Earth, it's affected by gravity and friction acting 
against it, but the law accepts that it will keep moving since there is 
nothing to stop it in space.

Newton's Second law isn't really that important. It just states that force 
is equal to the mass multiplied by the acceleration. f=ma

Newton's Third law states that for every action, there is an equal, 
opposite reaction.

This doesn't require gravity at all, just some kind of force that could 
happen in any part of the universe. 

So, as you can clearly see, gravity is not a requirement for Newton's laws 
to apply. They have yet to be disproven in literally any part of the 
universe, and are pretty reliable.

relative to the plane flying above me.

Newtons first law states that if something is moving it will carry on 
moving in the same direction at the same speed unless force is acted on it.

unless something applies a force to me (e.g my legs).

Just so you guys know. The ozone "hole" only occurs during winter months 
above the North Pole. This is because the polar vortexes( real ones, not 
the US version) there are strong enough to carry the CFC's into the ozone 
layer. However, when the CFC's react with the ozone both are destroyed. So 
when the polar vortexes are no longer strong enough to carry the CFC's up 
there, they dissipate. Meaning the depletion stops, and the hole actually 
regenerates. That's why the hole isn't there in the summer. ﻿

adversely affected jobwise, and so has our space system. No one wants to 
actually pay for it, but yet you have everyone stating that NASA should do

made up out of a meld of independent contracting companies or contractors,

funding it. What makes matters worse? If they manage to save on a project 
and don't go over budget or are underbudget, let's say, the government

the amount they needed...this year. That makes people spend money like 
crazy on stupid things, just to ensure they get the budget they need next

comments.text:
Nice term, +David DeNaples. :)

But actually, if you think about it, what it really means is that life 
changes fast.

I was born into a world without computers. Well, they existed, but not part 
of my life experience -- not until I was 9. My parents were born in a world 
without television -- well, they existed, but were not part of their life 
experience until they were teenagers in the 1950s. From "no television" to 
"internet and smartphones" in one lifetime. My grandparents were born into 
a world where most houses didn't have electricity.

human lifespan and dividing it by the total time that has accumulated in 
human history.  The part that does not make it relevant is that both 
variables are constantly changing.  The average human lifespan is currently 
increasing with the advancements of medicine, and the total human lifespan 
will continue to increase so long as humans are living.

comments.text:
+CuzEyeCan I'm sure you've heard of the Deist movement that arose during 
the Great Awakening of the 18th century. Deists believe that God created 
the universe and everything in it, but has since mostly left it to its own 
devices. They hold that God is best worshiped, not through strict 
ceremonies and religious services, but through service to one's fellow man 
the pursuit of knowledge. God doesn't need to play a visible or even play 
an active role at all in daily life for people to believe in Him. On the 
other hand, I'm reminded of John Milton's "Paradise Lost", in which Milton 
justifies Satan's existence by saying that God allows him to exist so that 
his evil can inspire acts of goodness. If it should seem that God has 
abandoned the world to hate and evil, perhaps it is because this hate and 
evil is meant to serve some such greater purpose that mankind, with our 
limited perspective, is unable to comprehend. Thus people like me believe 
in a God who appears to do nothing for His people. Just my opinion, not 
saying you have to start.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
This picture is

about a year and a half old.
But the pyramids themselves

are much older than that.
How much older? Well, think of it this way.
The Pyramids of Giza were as
old to the ancient Romans as the ancient Romans

are to us.
When the pyramids were being built
there were woolly mammoths living on Wrangel Island.

That's pretty old.
But don't get too impressed.
We often learn about the past in units, separate

chapters, which distracts from the fact
that many chapters aren't

just nearer each other than you might think,
they are often

literally written on top of one another.
Anne Frank

and Martin Luther King Jr. were born
in the exact same year.
By the late 1960s humans had come a long way.

We've become a spacefaring species.
But while we were sending
the first probes to the Moon and Venus and Mars,

it was still illegal for a black person
and a white person to marry

in 16 states.
The guillotine
seems like a macabre artefact from bygone days

but it was last used by France to
officially behead a criminal

the year Star Wars came out.
While General Custer was fighting

native tribes on the American frontier,
the Brooklyn Bridge

was being build.
And there were people alive then
who would later watch the Moon landing on television.
We went from Custer's last stand to
Armstrong's first steps within the span
of a single human life.

But all of these stories,
from the pyramids to Julius Caesar to

you watching this video right now,
belong to an incredibly thin section
in the book

of human history.
Compared to what human life has
mainly been like here on earth, our current societies

are weird.
Weird is also an acronym used

by Jared Diamond in his new book
"The World Until Yesterday."

Jared Diamond wrote
"Guns, Germs, and Steel," "Collapse"
and he's here with me to talk about weird.
Weird, w-e-i-r-d,

is an acronym for "western, educated,
industrial, rich and democratic."

When we talk about human nature
we're really talking about

a narrow slice of society.
Traditional societies were

everybody in the world,
from the beginning of human evolution
6 million years ago until within the last

10,000 years for the first time we began
encountering strangers and then we
developed

writing and then we acquired kings.
All of these things that we take for granted

are matter of the last 5,000 - 10,000 years.
Or the Internet

or the media, they're a matter
of the last few decades.

The relative recency of weird societies
in the speed with which

information and knowledge increases
means that not that long ago

we thought some pretty strange things.
For instance,

in 1903 The New York Times predicted
that building a flying machine
would be possible in 1 to 10 million years.

Later that very same year
the Wright brothers flew at Kitty Hawk.
In 1908 it was said that no flying machine will

ever fly from New York to Paris.
Who made that

foolish prediction?
One of the Wright brothers.
In 1962 the Decca recording company

passed on a young rock band, saying
"we don't like their sound

and guitar music is on the way out."
The band in question

was the Beatles. Keith Moon 
and John Entwistle were said to have remarked
about a band called The New Yardbirds,
"that band so ill-conceived it will sink
like a balloon or a zeppelin made out of lead."

Well, Jimmy Page was not deterred.
In fact, he took that phrase

and made it his band's new name.
He removed the A, so it wouldn't be pronounced
"lead," and that's where we got Led Zeppelin.
There is evidence the Nazis weren't entirely convinced
Earth was a globe we lived on the outside of.

Instead, they figured the Earth's
continents were actually aligning

on the inside of a hollow concave surface
with the stars and moon and planets
in the middle. Seriously.

As the story goes, Doctor Heinz Fischer
was sent to Rügen Island

to spy on the British.
Now, the curvature of the earth would have made this
impossible.

But thinking the earth was shaped like
this, they pointed their telescopes
up at a 45 degree angle. Needless to say,

the experiment didn't work.
The Eiffel Tower's

inauguration and the Wall Street Journal
and "Starry Night"
and Coca-Cola and Nintendo and Adolf Hitler
all began in 1889.
As did a guy named Thomas Midgley Jr.
Celebrated in his time,
Midgley's legacy has since been tarnished by
the negative consequences of his inventions.
His list of contributions to society is
impressively disastrous.

In the late twenties, Midgley synthesized
the first chloro-fluorocarbons -

CFC - for which he won
the Society of Chemical Industry's

Perkin medal.
Only later did we realize
all of those tons of CFCs we were emitting

were eating away 4% of our
atmosphere's protective ozone layer
every decade. Like a virus, creating a
wound, unlikely to completely heal until me and you
have long been dead. In the early 1920s
Midgley discovered that by adding Tetraethyllead
to gasoline engine knocking could be reduced.

The American Chemical Society gave him
the 1923 Nichols' medal

for the discovery. There were other, safer
alternatives but General Motors jointly
owned a patent on Tetraethyllead

with Midgley.
They could make a profit on it, so they advertised it as
the best option and almost immediately nearly
every motor vehicle on earth was spewing
lead into our atmosphere
and soil, which put it in our blood,
lead poisoning for decades.
Currently, the reference for healthy children is a blood
lead content of less than 5 micrograms
per decilitre. After the popularization of Midgley's
leaded gasoline, 88% of children
in America had double that amount of lead in their

blood.
When leaded gasoline was finally phased out
in the 1970s, that percentage fell
to 9%. Lead is a neuro toxin.

Even light exposure,
like that caused by Midgley's invention,
can cause a decrease in intelligence and in increase

in anti-social behaviour.
Fordham University found that
in young adults the best predictor of delinquent
and violent behavior is literally the lead content

of their blood.
Chillingly, the rise and fall
of violent crimes by juveniles in the 20th century

tracks significantly closely with the
rise and fall of lead

in their blood when they were
preschoolers - all over the world.
Historian J. R. McNeill remarked that Midgley

had more impact on the atmosphere
than any other single

organism in Earth's history.
Midgley's
final invention was even worse.
Well, for him. In 1940 he contracted

polio.
To help his friends and family lift him from bed
he designed an intricate system of ropes and pulleys.
As was the story of his life, the invention seemed
brilliant at first, but four years later he became

accidentally entangled in the ropes
and his own invention
strangled him to death.
Midgley's life took up 0.55%

of human history.
And, roughly speaking, yours will too.
To put that in perspective, let's time travel,

starting right now.
We begin
100,000 years ago - the beginning of modern humans.
We are moving forward in time an entire millennia,

a thousand years, every second.
As you can see,

not much is changing.
Our modern world

will briefly flash at the end.
That's all it is. That's all it's been.
So be careful not to miss it.
And as always,
thanks for watching.
